Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: A weekly study slot is planned, and lessons could be shifted without losing continuity.
Story: I stared at the maintenance schedule pinned to the break room wall, my name circled in red for next week’s shutdown. As the only senior machine repairer, everyone expected me to lead the servicing—cleaning, calibrating, making sure every conveyor and press would run smoothly when production resumed. It was a big responsibility, and I took pride in it. But as I checked my calendar, my heart sank. The shutdown overlapped with the weekly study session I led for the children at our synagogue. Teaching them about our traditions, the stories of our people, was something I cherished. The parents trusted me to keep the lessons meaningful and consistent. I knew I could reschedule the class, but it would disrupt the rhythm we’d built, and some kids might miss out. At work, they needed my expertise; at the synagogue, the children needed my guidance. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to yield. I sat at my desk, torn, the expectations of my two roles pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which responsibility I would have to let down.
